questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
Scientists studied the effects of Drug A on cancer Cell Lines V-Z. Table 1 shows the organ of origin and the LD50 (the concentration necessary to kill 50% of cells) of Drug A for each cell line.



Six petri dishes were prepared, each with 1,000 cells from Cell Line V. Drug A was added to 5 of the dishes in different concentrations, and all 6 dishes were incubated for 72 hr. Then the drug was removed, and the surviving cells were incubated for 10 days. This procedure was repeated for Cell Lines W-Z. Figure 1 shows the percent colony formation (percent of the surviving cells that divided to form colonies) for each cell line at each concentration of Drug A.


Table 1 and Figure 1 adapted from Debra Ferguson et al, “Anti-tumor Activity of Orally Bioavailable Farnesyltransferase Inhibitor, ABT-100, ls Mediated by Antiproliferative, Proapoptotic, and Antiangiogenic Effects in Xenograft Models." ©2005 by American Association for Cancer Research.
questions.question: 1. According to Figure 1, as the concentration of Drug A increased, the percent colony formation for Cell Line Z:

questions.question: 2. Based on Table 1, Cell Line W was formed from tissue found in which system of the human body?

questions.question: 5. At which of the following concentrations was Drug A completely ineffective in preventing the surviving Cell Line V cells from dividing to form colonies?

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
Plants from Species X can be tall or short, and they can have red, pink, or white flowers. Height in Species X plants is controlled by Gene T, which has 2 alleles, T and t. Flower color in Species X plants is controlled by Gene R, which also has 2 alleles, R and r. To determine how height and flower color are inherited in Species X, a student conducted the following crosses.

Cross 1
Two tall Species X plants, each with the genotype Tt, were crossed. The numbers and phenotypes of the resulting offspring are shown in Table 1.


Cross 2
Two pink-flowered Species X plants, each with the genotype Rr, were crossed, and the numbers and phenotypes of the resulting offspring are shown in Table 2.



Cross 3
Two Species X plants, each with the genotype TtRr, were crossed. The numbers, genotypes, and phenotypes of the resulting offspring are shown in Table 3.
questions.question: 6. The ratio of tall offspring to short offspring in Cross 1 is closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 7. What was the genotype for Gene T in the offspring from Cross 2 ?

choices.D: Cannot be determined from the given information

questions.question: 9. Suppose a gardener wants to produce tall pink-flowered Species X plants. Based on the results of Cross 3, which of the following pairs of plants, if crossed, would produce offspring with this phenotype?

questions.question: 10. A student had hypothesized that the majority of the offspring from Cross 3 would be tall and have white flowers.Are the results shown in Table 3 consistent with this hypothesis?

choices.A: Yes; 31 of the offspring from Cross 3 were tall with white flowers.
choices.B: Yes; 119 of the offspring from Cross 3 were tall with white flowers.
choices.C: No; only 11 of the offspring from Cross 3 were tall with white flowers.
choices.D: No; only 31 of the offspring from Cross 3 were tall with white flowers.

questions.question: 11. Suppose a short red-flowered Species X crossed plant is with a short pink-flowered Species X plant. The percent of the resulting offspring with the genotype ttRr will most likely be closest to which of the following?

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
In 3 studies, students investigated the stiffness of rectangular metal beams (see Figure 1).



Using the apparatus shown in Figure 2, the students deformed each beam under a variety of conditions.



In each trial, the beam being tested was supported at 2 points that were 0.10 m apart and equidistant from the midpoint of the beam. The beam was subjected to a load, W, measured in newtons (N), at the midpoint of the beam. W was provided by weights placed on the platform of the apparatus. During deformation, each beam became slightly U-shaped (see Figure 3).



A dial on the apparatus registered the distance, D, the beam was deformed in multiples of 10-6 m. After D was measured, the load was removed, and the beam returned to its original shape.

The intrinsic stiffness of the metal composing a beam was represented by Young's modulus, E. The effect of the width and height of a beam (see Figure 1) on D was represented by the quantity I, given in m4.


Study 1
In Trials 1-4, students determined D for beams with different I (see Table 1). In every trial, W=20 N and E = 50×109 N/m².



Study 2
In Trials 5-8, students determined D for beams composed of Metals S-V, respectively. Each metal had a different value of E (see Table 2). In every trial, W = 20 N and I = 2.0 × 10³ m4.

Study 3
In Trials 9-12, students determined D for different W (see Table 3). In every trial, I = 2.0 × 10-9 m4 and E = 50 × 109 N/m².
questions.question: 12. Which of the following diagrams of the side view of a beam correctly portrays the direction(s) of the 3 forces that the apparatus exerted on the beam?

questions.question: 13. If, in Study 3, a trial had been conducted in which W = 25 N, D would most likely have been closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 17. Based on the results of Studies 1 and 2, for a given W, which of the following combinations of I and E would yield the stiffest beam?

questions.article:
When an oil is exposed to air, small amounts of reactive peroxides can form in the oil. If the peroxide concentration reaches a certain level, the oil will rapidly decompose to form acidic organic compounds such as formic acid.Scientists use an accelerated oxidation apparatus, AOA, to model this process on a short time scale (see diagram).



A 3 g oil sample is heated to a certain temperature. Starting at time = 0 min, dry air is bubbled through the sample at a constant rate. The flow of air carries organic acids produced in the sample into the flask containing water. The conductivity (ease of electric flow) of the water is monitored. The conductivity of the water stays relatively constant until the oil rapidly decomposes. As the oil rapidly decomposes, the conductivity sharply increases. The length of time from 0 min until this increase occurs is the induction period.

Biodiesels are renewable fuel oils typically made from soybeans. Scientists did 3 experiments to study 4 biodiesels (BD1-BD4). BD2 was a 50/50 mixture of BD1 and BD4 by volume.

Experiment 1
The induction period was determined for fresh samples of BD1-BD4 at 4 temperatures (see Figure 1).




Experiment 2
The induction period was determined for fresh samples of BD1-BD4 at 110oC. Each sample contained 1 of 4 antioxidants at a concentration of 500 mg/kg (see Figure 2). Antioxidants are compounds that can inhibit the decomposition of oils exposed to air.


Experiment 3
The induction period was determined for fresh samples of BD1-BD4 at 110℃. Each sample contained a different concentration of the antioxidant TBHQ (see Figure 3).
questions.question: 18. In Experiment 3, which of the biodiesels having a TBHQ concentration of 750 mg/kg decomposed most quickly in the AOA?

questions.question: 19. A chemist claims that if the antioxidant concentration in a biodiesel is increased from 500 mg/kg to 1,000 mg/kg, the biodiesel's stability will increase. The claim is inconsistent with the results in Experiment 3 for which biodiesel?

questions.question: 20. Suppose a set of trials had been done in Experiment 1 at 115℃. Which of the following would have been the most likely induction periods of BD2 and BD3 ?

questions.question: 21. A sample of fresh BD1 is tested in the AOA as in Experiment 1 and is found to have an induction period of 65 min. At which of the following temperatures was the test most likely conducted?

questions.question: 23. Suppose BD5 is made by mixing 250 mL of BD1 with 750 mL of BD4. If a sample of BD5 containing 500 mg/kg of TBCA were tested as in Experiment 2, its induction period would most likely be:

questions.article:
In wetlands, the herbicides atrazine and alachlor are removed from the water by plant uptake or by adsorption onto soil particles and subsequent bacterial decomposition. Atrazine can also spontaneously break down to form deethylatrazine (DEA).

Three pairs of herbicide-free wetlands were established for a study: open water (O1, O2), submergent (S1, S2), and emergent (E1, E2), as described in Table 1. On 1 day, atrazine was added to O1, S1, and E1 and alachlor was added to O2, S2, and E2 to produce an initial herbicide concentration of 25 g/L in the water in each wetland. Atrazine, alachlor, and DEA concentrations in the water were measured at intervals over the next 120 days (see Figures 1-3).
questions.question: 24. Assume that the volume of water in each wetland remained constant over the 120 days of the study. According to Figure 2, 120 days after alachlor was added, what percent of the original alachlor concentration remained in the water in E2 ?

questions.article:

Atrazine, alachlor, and DEA concentrations in the water were measured at intervals over the next 120 days (see Figures 1-3).
questions.question: 25. According to Figure 1, 50 days after atrazine was added, its concentration in the water in S1 compared to its concentration in the water in E1 was about:

questions.question: 26. According to Figures 1 and 3, in S1, as the atrazine concentration decreased, the DEA concentration:

questions.article:
In wetlands, the herbicides atrazine and alachlor are removed from the water by plant uptake or by adsorption onto soil particles and subsequent bacterial decomposition. Atrazine can also spontaneously break down to form deethylatrazine (DEA).

Three pairs of herbicide-free wetlands were established for a study: open water (O1, O2), submergent (S1, S2), and emergent (E1, E2), as described in Table 1. On 1 day, atrazine was added to O1, S1, and E1 and alachlor was added to O2, S2, and E2 to produce an initial herbicide concentration of 25 g/L in the water in each wetland. Atrazine, alachlor, and DEA concentrations in the water were measured at intervals over the next 120 days (see Figures 1-3).
questions.question: 27. Is the statement “Over the 120 days of the study, atrazine concentration was most reduced in the water in the open water wetland"supported by the data in Figure 1 ?

choices.A: Yes; 120 days after atrazine was added, its concentration was least in the water in O1.
choices.B: Yes; 120 days after atrazine was added, its concentration was least in the water in E1.
choices.C: No; 120 days after atrazine was added, its concentration was least in the water in O1.
choices.D: No; 120 days after atrazine was added, its concentration was least in the water in E1.

questions.article:
In wetlands, the herbicides atrazine and alachlor are removed from the water by plant uptake or by adsorption onto soil particles and subsequent bacterial decomposition. Atrazine can also spontaneously break down to form deethylatrazine (DEA).

Three pairs of herbicide-free wetlands were established for a study: open water (O1, O2), submergent (S1, S2), and emergent (E1, E2), as described in Table 1. On 1 day, atrazine was added to O1, S1, and E1 and alachlor was added to O2, S2, and E2 to produce an initial herbicide concentration of 25 g/L in the water in each wetland. Atrazine, alachlor, and DEA concentrations in the water were measured at intervals over the next 120 days (see Figures 1-3).
questions.question: 28. As shown in Figure 2, every time the alachlor concentrations in the water in O2, S2, and E2 were measured during the study, the concentrations in S2 and E2 were found to be very similar to the concentration in O2. The most likely explanation for this result is that in S2 and E2:

choices.A: plant uptake played a more significant role in removing alachlor than did adsorption onto soil particles followed by bacterial decomposition.
choices.B: plant uptake played a less significant role in removing alachlor than did adsorption onto soil particles followed by bacterial decomposition.
choices.C: adsorption onto soil particles followed by bacterial decomposition played a more significant role in removing alachlor than did breakdown to form DEA.
choices.D: adsorption onto soil particles followed by bacterial decomposition played a less significant role in removing alachlor than did breakdown to form DEA.

questions.article:
A science teacher tells students that a ball on a string is in motion, and that the speed of the ball, v, is measured twice in rapid succession and is found to be increasing. The teacher then asks each of 3 students to describe the ball's motion between and after the 2 measurements of v.

While analyzing the students' statements, consider the following information about the ball:
The amount of angular momentum of the ball, AM, equals mvr, where m is the ball's mass and r is the distance of the ball from a reference point.
The ball's kinetic energy, KE, equals .
 The ball's total mechanical energy, TME, equals KE + PE, where PE is potential energy that is available to be converted into the ball's KE. If TME remains the same during the ball's motion, then TME is said to be conserved.

Student 1
The ball and string are suspended from a ceiling, forming a pendulum, and the pendulum is swinging without friction(see Figure 1).



The speed v increases between the 2 measurements because the ball is approaching the lowest point in its path, Point L. At Point L, v has its greatest value; as the ball moves past Point L, v begins to decrease immediately. The decrease in v continues until the ball reaches one of the 2 end points of its path, Point A or Point B. Once the ball reaches an end point, it reverses its direction of motion, and v again begins to increase.

Student 2
One end of the string is threaded through a hole in a horizontal tabletop. While a student pulls down on the string, steadily decreasing r, the ball continuously slides without friction around the hole (see Figure 2).



The speed v increases between the 2 measurements because the product vr remains constant; v will continue to increase as r decreases.


Student 3
The ball is on a horizontal tabletop that is against a wall. The string, which is fastened to the wall, is elastic and has been stretched. The ball slides without friction toward the wall (see Figure 3).


Between the 2 measurements, the string is contracting, so v increases. Once the string is no longer stretched, v remains constant until the ball hits the wall. After the ball bounces off the wall, v remains constant until the string begins to stretch again, at which time v begins to decrease.
questions.question: 29. Based on Student 1's description of the ball's motion, compared to the ball's KE at Point A or Point B, the ball's KE at Point L is:

choices.A: greater, because v is greater at Point L.
choices.B: greater, because v is less at Point L.
choices.C: less, because v is greater at Point L.
choices.D: less, because v is less at Point L.

questions.question: 30. Based on Student 3's description, when the ball is moving away from the wall and is slowing down, PE is accumulating. Where is the accumulating PE being stored ?

questions.question: 31. Throughout the ball's motion as described by Student 1, does the amount of angular momentum of the ball, AM, remain constant?

choices.A: Yes, because although v does not remain constant, m and r do remain constant.
choices.B: Yes, because although r does not remain constant, m and v do remain constant.
choices.C: No, because although m and v remain constant, r does not remain constant.
choices.D: No, because although m and r remain constant, v does not remain constant.

questions.question: 32. Based on Student 2's description of the motion of the ball, as r decreases, how does the ball's KE change?

questions.question: 34. Suppose that TME is conserved throughout the ball's motion. Based on the information given, if TME = 100 ergs, KE and PE can simultaneously have which of the following values?

questions.question: 35. Suppose that when r = 5 cm, v = 20 cm/sec. Based on a statement by Student 2, when r = 15 cm, v equals a value closest to which of the following?

questions.article:
Consider an aqueous solution separated from pure H2O by a membrane permeable to H2O but impermeable to solute particles. H2O will flow from the region of lower particle concentration (the pure H2O) into the region of higher particle concentration (the solution). The pressure associated with this flow is the osmotic pressure, π, given in atmospheres (atm) by the equation:

π = 0.0821 × T × i × C

Table 1 defines the 3 variables in the equation.



Table 2 lists, for 8 substances, the value of i and the molar mass (the mass of 1 mole of a substance).



Figure 1 shows how π varies with C for aqueous NaCl solutions and aqueous glucose solutions at 3 temperatures.
questions.question: 36. Consider a solution for which C = 0.20 mole/L and π = 10 atm. Based on Figure 1, this solution is most likely an aqueous solution of:

Table 1 defines the 3 variables in the equation.



Table 2 lists, for 8 substances, the value of i and the molar mass (the mass of 1 mole of a substance).



Figure 1 shows how π varies with C for aqueous NaCl solutions and aqueous glucose solutions at 3 temperatures.
questions.question: 37. Compared to the mass of 1 molecule of glucose, the mass of 1 molecule of lactose is:

choices.A: smaller, because lactose has a smaller molar mass than does glucose.
choices.B: smaller, because lactose has a larger molar mass than does glucose.
choices.C: larger, because lactose has a smaller molar mass than does glucose.
choices.D: larger, because lactose has a larger molar mass than does glucose.

questions.article:
Consider an aqueous solution separated from pure H2O by a membrane permeable to H2O but impermeable to solute particles. H2O will flow from the region of lower particle concentration (the pure H2O) into the region of higher particle concentration (the solution). The pressure associated with this flow is the osmotic pressure, π, given in atmospheres (atm) by the equation:

π = 0.0821 × T × i × C

Table 1 defines the 3 variables in the equation.



Table 2 lists, for 8 substances, the value of i and the molar mass (the mass of 1 mole of a substance).



Figure 1 shows how π varies with C for aqueous NaCl solutions and aqueous glucose solutions at 3 temperatures.
questions.question: 38. How does the value of i for HCl differ from the value of i for MgCl2, and what is the meaning of the difference? The value of i for HCl is:

choices.A: lower, which means that each HCl dissolves in H2O to form fewer particles than does each MgCl2.
choices.B: lower, which means that each HCl dissolves in H2O to form more particles than does each MgCl2.
choices.C: higher, which means that each HCl dissolves in H2O to form fewer particles than does each MgCl2.
choices.D: higher, which means that each HCl dissolves in H2O to form more particles than does each MgCl2.

questions.article:

Table 2 lists, for 8 substances, the value of i and the molar mass (the mass of 1 mole of a substance).



Figure 1 shows how π varies with C for aqueous NaCl solutions and aqueous glucose solutions at 3 temperatures.
questions.question: 39. Suppose a 1 L solution is produced by dissolving 2 moles of KCl in H2O. Based on the information provided, π, in atm, of this solution at 290 K can be calculated using which of the following expressions?

questions.article:
Consider an aqueous solution separated from pure H2O by a membrane permeable to H2O but impermeable to solute particles. H2O will flow from the region of lower particle concentration (the pure H2O) into the region of higher particle concentration (the solution). The pressure associated with this flow is the osmotic pressure, π, given in atmospheres (atm) by the equation:

π = 0.0821 × T × i × C

Table 1 defines the 3 variables in the equation.



Table 2 lists, for 8 substances, the value of i and the molar mass (the mass of 1 mole of a substance).



Figure 1 shows how π varies with C for aqueous NaCl solutions and aqueous glucose solutions at 3 temperatures.
questions.question: 40. Suppose a new line showing how π varies for aqueous MgCl2 solutions at 340 K were added to Figure 1. How would this new line compare to the lines shown in Figure 1 for aqueous NaCl solutions and aqueous glucose solutions at 340 K ?

choices.A: The y-intercept would remain the same, but the slope of the line would be greater.
choices.B: The y-intercept would remain the same, but the slope of the line would be smaller.
choices.C: The y-intercept would be greater, but the slope of the line would remain the same.
choices.D: The y-intercept would be smaller, but the slope of the line would remain the same.
